column1: #Text=Enter QUARLOUS with the license, and EDGWORTH.
#Text=Well, sir, you are now discharged; beware of being spied hereafter.
#Text=Sir, will it please you, enter in here at Ursula’s, and take part of a silken gown, a velvet petticoat, or a wrought smock; I am promised such, and I can spare a gentleman a moiety.
#Text=Keep it for your companions in beastliness, I am none of them, sir.
#Text=If I had not already forgiven you a greater trespass, or thought you yet worth my beating, I would instruct your manners, to whom you made your offers.
#Text=But go your ways, talk not to me, the hangman is only fit to discourse with you; the hand of beadle is too merciful a punishment for your trade of life.
#Text=—I am sorry I employ’d this fellow, for he thinks me such; facinus quos inquinat, æquat.
#Text=But it was for sport; and would I make it serious, the getting of this license is nothing to me, without other circumstances concur.
#Text=I do think how impertinently I labour, if the word be not mine that the ragged fellow mark’d: and what advantage I have given Ned Winwife in this time now of working her, though it be mine.
#Text=He’ll go near to form to her what a debauched rascal I am, and fright her out of all good conceit of me: I should do so by him, I am sure, if I had the opportunity.
#Text=But my hope is in her temper yet; and it must needs be next to despair, that is grounded on any part of a woman’s discretion.

#Text=I would give, by my troth now, all I could spare, to my clothes and my sword, to meet my tatter’d soothsayer again, who was my judge in the question, to know certainly whose word he has damn’d or saved; for till then I live but under a reprieve.
#Text=Enter BRISTLE and some of the Watch, with WASPE.
#Text=Sir, you are a Welsh cuckold, and a prating runt, and no constable.
#Text=—Come, put in his leg in the middle roundel, and let him hole there.
#Text=You stink of leeks, metheglin, and cheese, you rogue.
#Text=Why, what is that to you, if you sit sweetly in the stocks in the mean time?
#Text=if you have a mind to stink too, your breeches sit close enough to your bum.
#Text=It is no matter how; pray you look off.
#Text=Nay, I’ll not offend you, Numps; I thought you had sat there to be seen.
#Text=And to be sold, did you not?
#Text=pray you mind your business, an you have any.
#Text=Cry you mercy, Numps; does your leg lie high enough?
#Text=How now, neighbour Haggise, what says justice Overdo’s worship to the other offenders?
#Text=Why, he says just nothing; what should he say, or where should he say?
#Text=He is not to be found, man; he has not been seen in the Fair here all this live-long day, never since seven a clock i’ the morning.
#Text=His clerks know not what to think on’t.
#Text=There is no court of Pie-poudres yet.
#Text=Enter others of the Watch with BUSY.
#Text=What shall be done with them, then, in your discretion?
#Text=I think we were best put them in the stocks in discretion (there they will be safe in discretion) for the valour of an hour, or such a thing, till his worship come.
#Text=It is but a hole matter if we do, neighbour Haggise; come, sir, [to Waspe.] here is company for you; heave up the stocks.
#Text=[As they open the stocks, Waspe puts his shoe on his hand, and slips it in for his leg.
#Text=I shall put a trick upon your Welsh diligence perhaps.
#Text=I do obey thee; the lion may roar, but he cannot bite.
#Text=I am glad to be thus separated from the heathen of the land, and put apart in the stocks, for the holy cause.
#Text=One that rejoiceth in his affliction, and sitteth here to prophesy the destruction of fairs and May-games, wakes and Whitson-ales, and doth sigh and groan for the reformation of these abuses.
